Award.AwardTitle: MRI Consortium: Acquisition of Instrumentation for High-Speed/Radiation-Hard Optical Electronics Design and Testing
Award.AbstractNarration: This MRI Consortium Acquisition Award provides support for particle physics groups at Ohio State University and Southern Methodist University to upgrade their electronic and diagnostic instrumentation, to allow them to lead the development of very high-speed optical data links for the upgrade of ATLAS experiment at the CERN Large Hadron Collider, Geneva, Switzerland. While the instrumentation will have direct impact on specific subsystems of ATLAS including the IBL (or insertable B layer) of the Pixel Detector and for Liquid Argon (LAr) Calorimetry, the instrumentation have will have broader applicability to a wide variety of applications requiring ultra high-speed data links. The intellectual merit of the work is directly related to the discovery potential of ATLAS, which with CMS in 2012 co-discovered a Higgs Boson. Following that discovery, the ATLAS collaboration has continued its search for evidence of other beyond the Standard Model physics including super symmetry, for which the pixel detector and LAr systems are central. This includes the study of final states containing third-generation quarks: b-quarks with decay vertices detected in the pixel system, and top quarks, with leptons and jets, whose energy (and missing energy) is a principal measurement responsibility of the LAr Calorimetry system. The broader impacts of the program include the enhancement to campus laboratories of the proponents, which will directly impact research and training of graduate and undergraduate students, and which is expected to foster interactions with other campus researchers in including those engineering and other science disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This MRI Consortium Acquisition Award provides supports for electronics and particle physics groups at the University of Houston to upgrade electronic and diagnostic instrumentation for the development of very high-speed data acquisition and optical data links for the upgrade of ATLAS experiment at the CERN Large Hadron Collider, Geneva, Switzerland. The instrumentation allows both time-domain and frequency-domain measurements, and include a bit-error-rate tester (BERT), a mixed-signal oscilloscope, an arbitrary waveform generator (AWG) with a built-in logic analyzer, a vector network analyzer and a spectrum analyzer.  While the instrumentation has direct impact on specific subsystems of ATLAS experiments, the instrumentation also has broader applicability to a wide variety of applications requiring ultra-high-speed digital readout and optical data transmission. 

The instrumentation acquired through this MRI award are now being extensively used at the University of Houston and its collaborating institutions to tackle the critical issues of digitization interface design and to carry out development and testing of integrated circuits and subsystems for high-energy physics experiments, including high-speed analog-to-digital converters (ADCs), high-speed serializers and optical data links, low-jitter high-speed phase-locked-loops (PLLs) and delay-locked-loops (DLLs), low-noise detector front-end amplifier and shaper circuits, and laser and modulator drivers.  These developments are expected to lead to a new paradigm of high-performance, low-cost detector front-end data acquisition and transmission systems with high flexibility, scalability, and extended lifetime.

The broader impacts of this award include the enhancement to campus laboratories, which directly impacts research and training of graduate and undergraduate students, and which is expected to foster interactions with other campus researchers in both engineering and science disciplines. Students from different disciplines have been using the instrumentation to learn data acquisition and transmission system design and to acquire practical hands-on experiences. The data acquisition and transmission systems developed can also be readily used in undergraduate- or graduate-level instructional labs.
